_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan

California Accidental Release Prevention Program

Enterprise Rocklin Terminal & Storage

RMP Executive Summary





The Enterprise Rocklin Terminal is a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) storage facility.  The process is regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and Cal OSHA Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, Title 8 California Code of Regulations 5189 and 19 California Cod of Regulations 2735 California Accidental Release Prevention Program.  This is a RMP/CalARP Program Level 3 facility.



At the Enterprise Rocklin Terminal and Storage, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.



The prevention program is based on the requirements of 19 California Code of Regulations 2735 California Accidental Release Prevention Program and includes the following:  Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor Evaluation, Contractor and Visitor Orientation, Pre-Job Start-Up Review, Mechanical Integrity, Code of Safe Work Practices (Hot Work Permit, Confined Space Entry, Control of Hazardous Energy), Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Planning and Response, and Compliance Audit.



The Enterprise Rocklin Terminal and Storage is owned and operated by Enterprise Products Operating L.P.



We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help provide for the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and imp

lemented, including:



* A description of our facility and use of substances required by EPA's RMP regulation and the processes involved

* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases

* Emergency Response Programs

* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Rocklin Terminal that are regulated by EPA?s RMP rule.  





Facility Description



The Enterprise Rocklin Terminal is a Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) storage facility. The process is regulated by Cal OSHA Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, Title 8 California Code of Regulations 5189 and 19 California Code of Regulations 2735 California Accidental Release Prevention Program.  This is a RMP/CalARP Program Level 3 facility.



The Enterprise Rocklin facility receives odorized propane via railcar and transport truck. The propane is stored in eighteen 30,000 gallon capacity storage tanks.  These tanks are used for distribution to the truck transport loading docks for eventual distribution to propane retailers.



All of the previously mentioned tanks are administratively controlled to hold and not exceed 85% of their capacity.



In our process we use the following chemicals/flammables that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:



Toxics



No toxic materials to report.



Flammables



Propane is the product handled at the Enterprise Rocklin Terminal and Storage which is the only flammable substance that is maintained in a quantity above the EPA?s threshold quantities listed in 40 CFR 68.115.  At this facility there are three banks of tanks, six tanks per bank.  The tanks have a water capacity of 30,000 gallons each and are not allowed to exceed the maximum capacity of 85 % full (646,500 lbs.)





Key Off

site Consequence Analysis Scenarios



The EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenarios(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.



Worst Case Release Scenario ? Regulated Toxic Chemical



At the present time there are no regulated toxic chemicals to report for the Rocklin Terminal.



Alternate Release Scenario(s) ? Regulated Toxic Chemical



At the present time there are no regulated toxic chemicals to report for the Rocklin Terminal.



Worse Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals



This simulation involves the failure of one bank of propane storage tank resulting in a simulated vapor cloud explosion.  The entire inventories of all six tanks are simuilated due to the fact that all of the valves on the individual banks are normally open and tied into a single header.  This scenario assumes there would be no mitigation.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the public would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the specified reporting data elements of the Risk Management Plan

 

Alternate Case Scenario ? Regulated Flammable Chemicals



The alternate release scenario is a simulated rupture of the supply pipe to the loading docks resulting in a ten minute release and simulated vapor cloud explosion.  The maximum distance to the 1-psi overpressure endpoint for this scenario is 0.2 miles.  This scenario assumed that a tuck loading pump continued to operate at a rate of approximately 255 gallons per minutes (gpm) for 10 minutes after the line break.  The simulation calculated that 10,800 pounds of material were released in the assumed time frame.  



Mitigation measures wer

e taken into account when selecting the alternative release scenario.  These measures consisted of reviewing the use of emergency shutdown valves, pull-away shutdown system, location operator in attendance during product transfers.  Activation of the Emergency Shutdown Devices would isolate the source of the material and secure the facility.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur. 





Emergency Response Program



Enterprise maintains an emergency response plan in compliance with local emergency response agencies.  The Enterprise Rocklin Terminal has a Hazardous Material Business Plan that is accessible to the fire department in a box at the entrance of the facility.  Another copy of the Plan has been filed with the Placer County Environmental Health Department.  The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.



In the event of an accidental release, the facility operators are trained to shut off the source of fuel from a safe location or activate one of the shutdown devices, contact 9-1-1, evacuate personnel and secure the area.





General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Enterprise takes a systematic, protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  Our Process Safety Management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention program, including:



* Process safety information

* Process hazard analysis

* Operating procedures

* Training

* Mechanical integrity

* Management of change

* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"

* Compliance audits

* Incident investigation

* Employee participation

* Hot work permit

* Contractors



There is an on-going inspection program designed to search out and find deficiencies with the process equipment

prior to any incident.



Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.



The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazards.  Enterprise is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.





Accident History



Records are kept for all significant accidental releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:



Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had an accidental release.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The following is a list of improvements that are planned for implementation at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:



* Enterprise Products Operating recently acquired the facility from Coast Energy and is in the process of implementing the Enterprise Process Safety Management Systems. 

* The facility is considering adding hazardous gas detection and security monitoring devices to improve safety.





RMP Executive Summary    Page 3 of 4    11/29/2005
